Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is a civil action brought by Plaintiff Jessica Collins (“Plaintiff”) against her landlord, Defendant Mark Thompson (“Defendant”), for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 14, arising from Defendant’s failure to repair electrical defects that rendered a portion of Plaintiff’s leased apartment uninhabitable.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, as this action involves a landlord-tenant dispute regarding a residential tenancy within the jurisdiction of the Western Division Housing Court Department.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair violates the landlord’s statutory duty to maintain the premises in compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.351 (requiring that every habitable room be provided with adequate electrical service).

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord “shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Massachusetts law implies a covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential lease.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly refers to an "implied covenant" or "implied warranty of quiet enjoyment" in favor of these residential tenants and treats the landlords’ breach of that implied covenant as the basis for constructive eviction and non‑liability for rent. Although the case does not explicitly say "Massachusetts law implies a covenant of quiet enjoyment in every residential lease," it clearly assumes such an implied covenant exists in residential leases and applies it as settled Massachusetts law.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: The judge found that the tenants were “very substantially deprived” of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises “for a substantial time” (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). ... Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment...

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant is breached when a landlord, by act or omission, subjects the tenant to serious interference with her tenancy.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court expressly explains the meaning of “quiet enjoyment,” citing prior cases, as the tenant’s right to be free from serious interferences with the tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or omissions. It then applies that principle to hold that the landlord’s failure to prevent repeated flooding, a serious interference, constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant is breached when the landlord’s acts or omissions subject the tenant to serious interference with her tenancy.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]).… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s continued inaction despite knowledge of the defect amounts to “indirect interference” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that the landlord’s liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 can be based on omissions that seriously interfere with the tenancy, but it does not characterize that failure to repair as “indirect interference” or interpret that specific statutory phrase. The court focuses on “acts or omissions” that “impair the value of the leased premises” and applies that standard to the landlord’s knowing failure over nine years to correct the ventilation defect. Thus, while the case supports liability for inaction, it does not specifically ground that in the concept of “indirect interference” under § 14.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14… A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’ … Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem … for over nine years…. On these facts … we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”

Cruz Management Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass.raw_text: Cruz Management Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994)
Cruz Management Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that significant loss of use due to defective housing conditions violates the covenant.
Cruz Management Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the implied warranty of habitability and notes that the trial judge also found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not analyze what constitutes a violation of that covenant or link it specifically to ‘significant loss of use’ from defective conditions. The covenant of quiet enjoyment claim is mentioned only briefly and damages were not awarded on it, with no doctrinal discussion. Thus, the case cannot fairly be cited as authority that Massachusetts courts recognize significant loss of use due to defective housing conditions as a violation of the covenant; other cases like Simon v. Solomon fill that role instead.
Cruz Management Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that significant loss of use due to defective housing conditions violates the covenant.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that if the tenants are truly unable to use common areas such as sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas because of conditions on the premises, this constitutes a serious interference with quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. That directly recognizes that significant loss of use of housing facilities due to defective or harmful conditions can violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth., 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises…. If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: A landlord’s ongoing failure to maintain essential services such as heat, electricity, or water can support damages under the statute.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat—an essential service—during the heating season breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment and gives rise to civil damages under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The Appeals Court reverses the lower court and directs that the tenant is entitled to a declaration of violation, injunctive relief requiring provision of heat, and an assessment of damages and attorney’s fees under the statute. This directly supports the proposition that an ongoing failure to maintain essential services can support statutory damages.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: "A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season...constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment... On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to (a) a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14; (b) an injunction ordering that heat be provided...; and (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14."

Davis v. Allard, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 508 (.raw_text: Davis v. Allard, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 508 (1994)
Davis v. Allard, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 508 (.proposition: A landlord’s ongoing failure to maintain essential services such as heat, electricity, or water can support damages under the statute.
Davis v. Allard, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 508 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns negligence and comparative fault arising from an automobile accident near a racetrack and issues of collateral estoppel from prior criminal proceedings. It does not involve a landlord-tenant relationship, essential services in rental housing, or statutory damages related to failure to provide heat, electricity, or water. Therefore it provides no authority for the claimed landlord-tenant statutory proposition.
Davis v. Allard, 37 Mass. App. Ct. 508 (.relevant_excerpt: Davis based his case against Wonderland on two theories: that the described system in use in and about the crosswalk for getting the crowd over the highway was intrinsically inadequate and contributed to the accident, and Wonderland should and could have done better; and that the officer on the particular occasion behaved negligently and Wonderland was responsible for the consequences.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The duty to maintain habitable premises arises under both G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses the landlord’s obligations in terms of the State Sanitary Code and related housing statutes (primarily G.L. c. 111 and c. 239), and advocates treating those legal standards as implied terms of the tenancy. It does not state that the duty to maintain habitable premises arises under G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it link habitability directly to that statute. The focus is on the Sanitary Code and its enabling provisions, not c. 186, § 14, so the proposition as framed is broader than what this opinion supports.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code adopted by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health under authority delegated to it by the Legislature (G. L. c. 111, § 5, later repealed, and § 127A). The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. … It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: The duty to maintain habitable premises arises under both G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses violations of the State Sanitary Code and a separate claim for breach of the warranty of habitability, and also addresses G.L. c. 186, § 15B (security deposits), but it does not mention G.L. c. 186, § 14 at all. Nor does it state that the duty to maintain habitable premises arises under both § 14 and the State Sanitary Code. The decision therefore cannot be cited as authority for that specific dual statutory/source proposition.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: "Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. ... D. Breach of Warranty of Habitability. Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability... The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations. McKenna, 5 Mass. App. Ct. at 308."

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: The duty to maintain habitable premises arises under both G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.

Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.raw_text: Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959 (1985)
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.proposition: Defendant’s inaction has deprived Plaintiff of the beneficial use of a substantial portion of her apartment, constituting constructive partial eviction and actionable interference.
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.support_reasoning: The opinion finds serious habitability defects and violations of the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, and awards emotional distress damages under G.L. c. 186, §14. However, it does not analyze or label the situation as a constructive (partial) eviction, nor does it frame the harm specifically as loss of beneficial use of a substantial portion of the apartment in constructive-eviction terms. The case supports landlord liability for uninhabitable and soot-damaged premises, but not the specific constructive partial eviction proposition stated.
Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959.relevant_excerpt: 1. The defendants were seriously at fault in failing to bring the plaintiffs’ apartment into habitable condition and to keep it so. Most grievous among the defects was the lamentable condition of the oil fired furnace and connected heating apparatus, which was supposed to deliver clean heat to the apartment, but in fact corrupted it and all within it with clinging soot. ... The defendants were also found, with respect to the condition of the apartment, to have violated the implied warranty of habitability ... and the covenant of quiet enjoyment (see c. 186, § 14) ... .
